prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for expecting my wife to put her married name on her doctoral certificate, as opposed to her maiden name.
So my wife will be graduating dental school in May and she brought up to me that she would like to practice under our married last name but have her doctoral certificate in her maiden name. Not sure if that's even possible but that's not the concern. I feel as though it's kind of a betrayal to our unity because we have been married the entire time she has been in school minus her freshman year of undergrad and we have both sacrificed alot, surviving primarly on my income (understandably as im older and make significantly more as im already 10 years into my career, and she is in school), countless hours of flipping flash cards, and taking the majority share of housework so she could focus on schooling and her wanting to use her maiden name makes me feel like she isn't recognizing our joint sacrifice and contributions to get us there. I just don't want to walk into her office and people look at the certificate with her maiden name and assume we got married after all that work happened. We did this together and should celebrate it together. 

She feels that since she works full time and goes to school full time, and has paid for the majority of her tuition she feels like she should take pride in her family's name and that I wasnt going to class with her that she deserve that recognition. 

We have a very happy, long marriage and its more of a debate than a fight (actually posting this together) so let us know what you think.
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So the situation is about a husband and wife discussing whether the wife should use her married name on her doctoral certificate instead of her maiden name. The husband feels that using her maiden name is a betrayal to their unity, given that they've been married through most of her schooling and both have made sacrifices. The wife argues that she worked full-time, paid for most of her tuition, and that the husband didn't attend classes with her, so she deserves the recognition under her family name.

First, I need to consider the key points. The husband is emphasizing joint sacrifice and unity, wanting to publicly show their partnership through her using his last name on the certificate. The wife, on the other hand, wants to maintain her maiden name for personal recognition of her own achievements and her family's support.

Is the husband justified in feeling slighted? Well, changing one's name on academic certificates is a personal decision. In many countries, professionals do retain their maiden names on diplomas and in practice. The husband's concern about others assuming they married after her degree might stem from a desire for public recognition of their partnership, but that's more about perception than actual fact. The wife's argument about her personal contribution and financial responsibility for her education seems valid too. She's highlighting her own efforts and the support from her family's name, which is her right.

The husband's argument might be based on a desire for unity, but it could also be seen as imposing his values onto her. Name choice is a personal matter, and expecting someone to change their name for symbolic reasons might not be fair. The wife's stance is about her identity and achievements, which are her own. The husband's sacrifices are real, but they don't necessarily require her to change her name as a sign of unity.

Another angle: financial contributions. The husband supported them financially, but the wife paid for most of her tuition. That's a significant point. If she's paying for her education, she might feel more ownership over the degree's recognition. The husband's support is part of their partnership, but it doesn't necessarily mean her name should reflect his family's name.

Also, societal norms vary. In some cultures, taking the husband's last name is traditional, but in others, people choose to keep their maiden names. The wife's decision might align with her personal values or those of her family. The husband's feeling of betrayal might be more about his own expectations rather than the wife's wrongdoing.

In terms of fairness, the husband is asking for something symbolic (the name on the certificate) to reflect their unity, but the wife is asserting her individuality and contributions. Neither is entirely wrong, but the husband's expectation might not be reasonable. The name choice is her decision, and she's not obligated to change it to honor their partnership. The husband's sacrifices are important, but they don't necessitate her to use his name for recognition.

So, considering all this, the author (the husband) might not be in the wrong for feeling slighted, but his expectation that she should use his name could be seen as imposing his will on her personal choice. Therefore, the answer might lean towards A, the author is in the wrong because he's not respecting her autonomy in name choice.
